job_title: Volunteer in New York, NY
pros: Working with mentors who work in the industry
cons: Long hours Unpredictable scehdule Competative environment

job_title: Graduate Student in New York, NY
pros: The museum is cool and they have a great resources in the library. I enjoy their historic archives. Its fun learning and going to school for fashion. Being surrounded by creatives is also very nice for building and expanding your own creative mind.
cons: They don't have a helpful administration and registration office. People are quite rude and not helpful including a lot of the working faculty. They treat their college students like high schoolers.

job_title: Sergeant in New York, NY
pros: Great Benefits, Amazing Staff and people, Pay raises frequently, opportunity for growth
cons: Low base pay, Management/HR does not work in your favor , Disciplinary actions will be taken if you do no adhere to their feelings.

review_title: Great for first job, very inspiring
job_title: Tutor in New York, NY
pros: Great people to work with
cons: Low pay but pretty okay compare to time you are working

job_title: Student Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Amazing place and people Great benefits Flexible work schedule
cons: A lot of rules and things to keep in mind, though pro staff member are always there for help

job_title: Adjunct Associate Professor in New York, NY
pros: Students, Pension, and the Union
cons: Commute and more Adjuncts than enough classes available for them

job_title: Assistant Director in New York, NY
pros: The summer schedule is fun to have.
cons: Just an old-fashioned bullying mill where the past is the present is the future. While the chief tyrant left for another school and got fired within a year, the bullying culture remained. The president keeps the bored in a cocoon on what's happening on campus.

job_title: Academic Tutor in New York, NY
pros: Can choose hours and subjects Great office Great supervisors
cons: Limited to working part time, but it made since since I was working while being a student

job_title: Adjunct Faculty in New York, NY
pros: Teaching talented students, best library and archive museum.
cons: *Bizarre peer review ritual that is not constructive and detrimental * lack of planning in hiring process, *poor internal communication with management, *non-flexible support system: xerox copy making and other services( supplies, keys) need to be booked 2 weeks in advance. *internal email/computer access has a long lag

job_title: Adjunct Faculty in New York, NY
pros: Flexibility and ability to teach independently.
cons: Salary and maximum credits as an adjunct. No benefits

job_title: Director in New York, NY
pros: Great benefits, 401k, great vacation package
cons: not much opportunity for advancement

job_title: Adjunct Professor in New York, NY
pros: Talented students. Status as a professor teaching at one of the top fashion colleges.
cons: Underpaid. You will make approx $7000 after taxes for one class per semester. Adjuncts are preferred because of budget restraints so be warned that there is little chance to be hired full time. Adjuncts are only paid for class hours and not paid for extra activities, such as class preparation or staff meetings. You need a thick skin because there is a lot of back-stabbing from other professors and students can leave unkind anonymous reviews. The president's office is swanky but there is no funding for supplies such as sewing needles, so the professors end up spending their own money.

job_title: Adjunct Professor in New York, NY
pros: Experienced faculty and students with a desire learn about the fashion industry.
cons: Low and uncompetitive hourly wage. Union standardized wage and not based on individual experience.

job_title: Adjunct Professor in New York, NY
pros: pay rate increases yearly. union looks out for faculty.
cons: Need to have better, more affordable health insurance for adjunct faculty

job_title: Adjunct Instructor in New York, NY
pros: Great colleagues that ensure your success
cons: Not a lot of lunges for faculty

job_title: Adjunct Professor in New York, NY
pros: Hardworking kids with a good lense of the future
cons: SUNY pay so adjuncts do not make a lot at all

job_title: Information Technology Instructor(IT Instructor) in New York, NY
pros: Free tuition for staff members who belong to the union. Relatively diverse workforce. Hard working students.
cons: Annoying office politics. Some offices render substandard customer service to the students.

job_title: Resident Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Friendly environment to work at!!
cons: Long hours to be an RA.

job_title: Student Lab Monitor in New York, NY

job_title: Adjunct Professor in New York, NY
pros: FIT is filled with terrific talent in the teaching staff.  The students are engaged and motivated and work hard in the classes which makes teaching at this university fun.
cons:
Administration isn't as communicative as it needs to be to help guide the pedagogy and the programs so we can all be on the same page.
Unpaid hours for prep work and unrealistic work loads for the hours of your time that you're paid for.

review_title: Its an OK position for entry level

pros: Consistent Schedule , Flexible Schedule, Friendly community

cons: The position expires when you graduate. Other than that there are no cons!

pros: good pay. good benefits. loved all staff

job_title: Assistant Professor in New York, NY

job_title: Adjunct Professor in New York, NY

job_title: Social Media Manager in New York, NY
pros: it was okay, switched to remote
cons: after switched to remote didn't do much

job_title: Program Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: salary, benefits, vacation time, location
cons: workload, culture, communication, support, career opportunities

job_title: Adjunct Faculty in New York, NY
pros: Good opportunities to engage with students and develop teaching and assessment.
cons: Too bureaucratic: faculty who know nothing about each other get to vote on renewing contracts.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Professors are industry professionals with connections
cons: Nothing at the moment, thank you

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: I have learned a lot and love being here
cons: There can be a lot of work, but it is okat

review_title: Worked there for 10 years, went above and beyond, never got a promotion.
job_title: Building Manager in New York, NY
pros: Got to take classes for free. The position provided me with a small studio apartment in Chelsea that was inside the residence hall.
cons: I went above and beyond what was required of my position and then it was made into what I was required to do. I applied for a promotion several times and never got it. The position was part time and required you to live in the residence hall but it was almost impossible to get another job because the hours were inflexible. My direct supervisor was unable to use my preferred pronoun after asking several times.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: The benefits and work-life balance here are great, as are the students - it's a great place for anyone who cares about the fashion industry or art/design in general. There's a high potential to be creative if you like.
cons: Bureaucracy central! Getting anything done requires 20+ steps routed through multiple supervisors. There's some kind of taboo on asking anyone for anything directly, and some people are really focused on maintaining the little fiefdoms over which they have control rather than actually moving the organization forward. Also, you won't get promoted without several years of wrangling with management. (That said, this all varies between different departments.)

job_title: Administrator in New York, NY
pros: Lots of vacation time (30 for Administrators), (20 for others non-union), plus sick and personal.  All possible holidays, always off when there's a drop of snow.  Retirement center.
cons: Everything, they hired unqualified individuals to run a department, they also promote employees not based on qualifications (example: having a director without a degree or experience, or hiring a consultant (non employee) to run a department that impacts future decisions, directors crossing the line bordering sexual harassment).  They had Executive Director/VP go AWOL.  Somehow this college president decided to turn a blind eye.  So outdated on everything.   This place will never make it to the Best Place To Work.

review_title: Pleasant place to work with good pay/ benefits but not much room for growth.
job_title: Human Resources Associate in New York, NY
pros: Laid back vibe, Generous benefits package, strong union means a secure job from which you can retire, yearly raises (albeit small increments), punching out at 5 on the dot guilt free, Tenure.
cons: No growth within your department...HR is leaning towards outsourcing all new positions.  Mundane, repetitive work.  Will not "grow".  A lot of people are jaded after having been there so many years and have a "who gives a crap" attitude which can be draining.

job_title: Technologist C in New York, NY
in New York, NY
pros: good benefits, i really can't think of anything else honestly.
cons: extremely disorganized, politics reigns, meritocracy does not exist here.  the union is useless except for their negotiation of benefits.  they allow people to continue to work here despite their lack of education or computer experience and training is not mandatory.  once you're 'tenured' there's very little you need to do to prove yourself except to show up in the morning and leave at 5, and you will still get a fat paycheck for being an idiot that happens to have a job.

job_title: Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Creative environment, great colleagues, the benefit of working with and assisting an international group of talented and interesting  students and visitors. FIT has an active Union that’s helped negotiate (and continues to do so) many benefits for their employees, faculty  like free tuition for spouses and kids, competitive salaries with incremental raises, sick, vacation and time off pd, 401k, etc.  Also, you get to work a 4 day week in the summer months.
cons:
I’ve worked in a few departments at the school over a 20 year period and your experience will depend greatly on where you work within the school. This will greatly depend on you and your preferences so just be sure to have any concerns and questions about expectations and environment ready if you interview here.

The college maintenance management facilities can be difficult to get results from (ie- work orders, basic maintenance) there is a strange system in place with the co. (ABM) where communication and deadlines are nearly nonexistent. This can be very frustrating.

The security equipment and facilities need to be modernized. The security team is efficient and attentive but from what I’ve learned, not always trained well and not paid competitively enough.

Some of the college has been renovated but there needs to be more modernization and design improvements. Especially to the bathrooms and classrooms. 

Temperature issues are a continuous problem- too cold or too hot.

review_title: Good paying part time job with tuition exemption
job_title: Technician in New York, NY
pros: Tuition exemption for you and family members as only part time staff. High hourly wage and a very casual work environment. Students are pretty entertaining and diverse.
cons: Weird hours for scheduling. Have to work one weekend day. No room for growth and no affordable options for healthcare for part time employees unless you work there for 6 years to get a partial reduction in cost.

job_title: Adjunct Professor in New York, NY
pros: FIT recruits great industry people to come teach and lecture at the school.  I always meet interesting and engaged people there.
cons: Onboarding, operational staffing needs work.  There's not much focused assistance in getting your classes started.  Some of the support staff lack the motivation and the understanding to be really helpful to those their charged to help.

review_title: They treat their employees well here; people are generally happy.
job_title: Tutor in New York, NY
pros: Treat employees good; good benefits and hours if salaried. Can easily move into other higher positions if they come open, once you're in! Free classes if salaried.
cons: No HR commuter, health, or vacation benefits for most employees who aren't full time or salaried. You have to try hard and aggressively apply to higher jobs, or you could stay in a dead end hourly job forever.

review_title: Writing Studio is one of the most pleasant FIT departments
job_title: Peer Writing Tutor in Chelsea, NY
pros:
Very motivated department directors
Many valuable learning experiences
Fun projects to promote growth as tutors and writers
Pleasant environment (with plants and sunlight)
The director fought FIT to get our pay raised to a livable wage-- he really respects his employees!
cons: Limited hour availability (you won't get more than 11 hours as a peer tutor, which was fine with me since I was a busy student)

review_title: one of the most productive thing you can do as a student
job_title: Academic Tutor in New York, NY
pros: you can utilize your free time as each appointment lasts for an hour and you can plan your schedule in advance. Great to see students who are willing to learn, and you can review what you have learned by sharing your knowledge to others
cons: some students expect you to do their homework and you have to find the balance

review_title: Manager User Support Services and Media
job_title: IT User Support Services and Media Manager in Clifton, NJ
pros: Great place wot work, Scope to explore different technology and learn a lot. Ability to work on multiple different projects at the same time, work cross department in IT regarding the above mentioned.
cons: Since this is a Union Job there is a salary cap and no room for financial growth.

job_title: Student Services Representative II in New York, NY
pros: Great Salary and benefits. Its a union jobs so there are salary increase.  The best part if the opportunity to take classes for free
cons: Lazy workers and incompetent supervisor's.  Once you get tenure its hard to be fired and half of the tenured staff do nothing.

job_title: Adjunct Lecturer in New York, NY
pros: Face to face class the amount of time I spend can be mostly done at home in my home office, folks are generally collegiate and easy to get along with, the pay checks clear at the bank.
cons: Salaries are competitive with Union Shops but less so against private institutions.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Brooklyn, NY
pros: The staff is very knowledgeable and easy to work with. The hours are flexible.  The pay is reasonable and it is a very easy going and comfortable environment.
cons: The lab can be very slow at times so you must find other things to keep your time occupied. You are often alone.

job_title: Professor in New York, NY
pros:
Excellent working conditions 
Outstanding Union which represents faculty, staff, classroom assistant and adjuncts
Employment protections for all adjunct faculty
Great benefits including retirement benefits
Very competitive salaries
Wonderful,creative student body
cons: Too many layers of administration which often makes it difficult to innovate and to get projects approved

job_title: Adjunct in New York, NY
pros: The courses are great to choose from and the schedules are very flexible. As faulty you can take classes for free.
cons: If you do not have a masters its almost impossible to become a full time professor. There can be to much politics at times.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: The school  as a whole has a great work-life balance practice with generous vacation time off to recharge, but all this depends on the manager's or supervisor's discretion.
cons: The different tiered system of vacation time off is difficult to understand.  Seniority matters a lot

job_title: Student Monitor in New York, NY
pros: Learned about 3D printing, laser cutting, fabric and specialty media printing within a very positive and relaxed environment.
cons: Due to the hours being spread out among a lot of students, I didn't get as many hours as I would have liked.

job_title: Full Time Faculty in New York, NY
pros: Diverse, motivated student population. Excellent support from administration & strong union benefits for both faculty and staff.
cons: Development of and implementation of new curriculum and policies often gets bogged down in procedure and red tape.

job_title: Adjunct Assistant Professor in New York, NY
pros: Pretty good facilities, decent union means you can have a degree of job security
cons: adjunct pay means that the security is sort of pointless.  it's a dead-end job.

review_title: Not a place for the ambitious
job_title: Student Representative in New York, NY
pros: PTO is great commuter benefits great and really good health insurance.
cons: Hard to move-up & everyone is content with the way things are even if it's not working

job_title: Instructor in New York, NY
pros: Great place to work with good support from management

job_title: Student Services Representative in New York, NY
pros: Great benefits and cool summer schedule.....free tuition.  Decent pay.
cons: There isn't really room for growth.  It's not that easy  to move up and you may feel stuck.

review_title: Help my department with any technical needs, also help students with information on our database

job_title: Office Associate in New York, NY

job_title: Administrator in New York, NY

cons: This is a rigid organization that is servile to senior management who are, frankly, quite mediocre (If that). Trying to do your job in an independent and professional manner will usually lead to the guillotine.  Frankly, it's not worth it IF you are trying to progress in your career.

review_title: Enjoyed my time as an RA at FIT
